Te Whare Tapa Whā: A Holistic Health Model

Learning Objectives

  • Understand the four dimensions of Te Whare Tapa Whā and how they contribute to wellbeing.
  • Reflect on personal wellbeing using this model.
  • Apply the model to real-life scenarios.
  • Respect and engage with Māori perspectives on health.

Cultural Context

Te Whare Tapa Whā is a Māori health model developed by Sir Mason Durie. It compares wellbeing to a wharenui (meeting house), where each wall represents a different aspect of health. If one wall is weak, the whole house is unstable.

Cultural Safety Note: Ensure respectful discussion of Māori concepts. Encourage students to engage with the model in a way that honours its origins.

The Four Dimensions

Taha Tinana (Physical Wellbeing)

Your body's health – exercise, nutrition, sleep, and physical safety.

Taha Hinengaro (Mental & Emotional Wellbeing)

Your thoughts, feelings, and mental resilience.

Taha Whānau (Social Wellbeing)

Relationships with family, friends, and community.

Taha Wairua (Spiritual Wellbeing)

Your sense of purpose, values, and connection to the world.

Activity: Personal Wellbeing Reflection

Task: Draw your own "whare" and rate each wall (1-5) based on your current wellbeing. Write one action to strengthen each dimension.

Discussion: Share in small groups (optional) – what patterns do you notice?

Assessment Suggestions

  • Self-assessment: Reflection journal on personal wellbeing.
  • Group task: Create a poster explaining Te Whare Tapa Whā.
  • Scenario analysis: Apply the model to a case study.

Extension Activities

  • Research another indigenous wellbeing model (e.g., Fonofale) and compare.
  • Interview a kaumātua about traditional Māori health practices.
  • Design a wellbeing program for your school using Te Whare Tapa Whā.

Adaptations for Diverse Learners

  • Visual learners: Use diagrams and colour-coding.
  • Kinesthetic learners: Build a 3D model of the whare.
  • ESOL students: Provide vocabulary lists and sentence starters.
  • Simplified version: Focus on one dimension at a time.

``` --- ## **Teacher Implementation Guide** ### **1. Introduction (10 mins)** - Begin with a karakia (optional, if appropriate for your school). - Explain the significance of Te Whare Tapa Whā as a Māori model of health. - Show an image of a wharenui and relate it to wellbeing. ### **2. Exploring the Four Dimensions (15 mins)** - Discuss each taha (dimension) with examples. - Ask students: *"Which dimension do you think is strongest for you? Why?"* ### **3. Activity: Personal Wellbeing Reflection (20 mins)** - Students draw their own whare and rate each wall (1-5). - Optional: Peer discussion in small groups. ### **4. Application (15 mins)** - Provide a case study (e.g., a student feeling stressed) and have students apply the model. ### **5. Wrap-up (10 mins)** - Reflect: *"How can this model help us support others?"* - Close with a whakataukī (proverb), e.g., *"He oranga ngākau, he pikinga waiora – Positive feelings in your heart enhance your wellbeing."* --- ## **Assessment Rubric** | **Criteria** | **Achieved** (🟡) | **Proficient** (🟢) | **Advanced** (🔵) | |--------------------------|----------------|----------------|----------------| | **Understanding of Te Whare Tapa Whā** | Can name the four dimensions | Explains each dimension clearly | Applies the model to real-life situations | | **Personal Reflection** | Identifies strengths/weaknesses | Explains impact on wellbeing | Sets meaningful goals for improvement | | **Cultural Respect** | Uses Māori terms correctly | Engages thoughtfully with the model | Makes connections to other indigenous perspectives | --- ## **Extension Activities** 1. **Comparative Study:** Research the Fonofale (Pasifika health model) and compare. 2. **Community Project:** Design a wellbeing initiative for your school based on Te Whare Tapa Whā. 3. **Creative Expression:** Write a poem or song representing the four dimensions. --- ## **Adaptations for Diverse Learners** - **For neurodiverse students:** Use structured templates for reflections. - **For reluctant writers:** Allow verbal or visual responses. - **For advanced learners:** Investigate how modern health science aligns with this model. This resource is ready for immediate classroom use, aligns with the NZ Curriculum (Health & PE, Social Sciences), and supports culturally responsive teaching. **Ngā mihi nui!**
